xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work is supported by grants from the Agricultural Research Development Agency (ARDA), Thailand Research Fund (TRF) and Mahidol University (grant RSA5680006 ), and the Center of Excellence on Medical Biotechnology (CEMB) , S&T Postgraduate Education and Research Development Office (PERDO) (to C.M.). Financial supports from the NSTDA Chair Professor grant, the Faculty of Science, Mahidol University , and the Office of the Higher Education Commission and Mahidol University under the National Research Universities Initiative are also gratefully acknowledged (to C.M.). C.M. is TRF Research Scholar.

organization.$: Thailand Center of Excellence for Life Sciences (TCELS)
Center of Excellence on Medical Biotechnology

head.citation-title: Chitosan oligosaccharide suppresses tumor progression in a mouse model of colitis-associated colorectal cancer through AMPK activation and suppression of NF-κB and mTOR signaling
head.abstracts: © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.Novel, effective and safe agents are needed for the chemoprevention of colorectal cancer (CRC). This study investigated the effects of chitosan oligosaccharides (COS) on CRC progression and their underlying mechanisms and safety profiles in mice. Using a mouse model of colitis-associated CRC, we found that oral administration of COS (500 mg/kg/day) resulted in a ∼60% reduction of tumor size and tumor numbers/sectioning. In addition, COS treatment increased AMPK activity, suppressed the NF-κB-mediated inflammatory response and reduced the expressions of cyclin D1, phosphorylated ribosomal protein S6, and MMP-9 in the colon tissues of these mice. Importantly, administration of COS (500 mg/kg/day; 50 days) had no adverse effects on renal or liver functions. Our results indicate that COS suppressed CRC progression via AMPK activation and the suppression of NF-κB and mTOR signaling. COS may be of potential utility in the chemoprevention of CRC.

grant-text.$: AcknowledgementsThis work is supported by grants from the Agricultural Research Development Agency (ARDA), Thailand Research Fund (TRF) and Mahidol University (grant RSA5680006), and the Center of Excellence on Medical Biotechnology (CEMB), S&T Postgraduate Education and Research Development Office (PERDO) (to C.M.). Financial supports from the NSTDA Chair Professor grant, the Faculty of Science, Mahidol University, and the Office of the Higher Education Commission and Mahidol University under the National Research Universities Initiative are also gratefully acknowledged (to C.M.). C.M. is TRF Research Scholar.

coredata.dc:description: Novel, effective and safe agents are needed for the chemoprevention of colorectal cancer (CRC). This study investigated the effects of chitosan oligosaccharides (COS) on CRC progression and their underlying mechanisms and safety profiles in mice. Using a mouse model of colitis-associated CRC, we found that oral administration of COS (500 mg/kg/day) resulted in a ∼60% reduction of tumor size and tumor numbers/sectioning. Our results indicate that COS suppressed CRC progression via AMPK activation and the suppression of NF-κB and mTOR signaling. COS may be of potential utility in the chemoprevention of CRC.
